text.text: (Porto-Gonçalves, Carlos Walter, , pp. 39-43).

The time intervals referenced here for Europe are based on definitions from the Britannica Encyclopedia. However, there is no single, universally applicable periodization for the entire region (Barzun, J. et al., , Europe History ; Violatti, C., , Idade da Pedra).

Prerequisites

To better understand the concept of time, we suggest that readers first study the following resources:

  • Natural Limits: Introduces the reader to the concept of limits using examples from the human body and liquids.

### Introduction

Humanity shares a common origin that stretches back millions of years, as we shall see in the following sections. This makes it tempting to try to group all of human history into common chronological periods.

One example of a temporal framework created for this kind of grouping is the **Three-Age System**, devised by Christian Jurgensen Thomsen to classify different periods of human prehistory: the Stone Age, Bronze Age, and Iron Age (<htcite0>; <htcite1>; <htcite2>). However, this type of classification warrants more careful reflection.

Reflection 1: Metallurgy or Stone

Would it be feasible to apply the three-age system to all of humanity?

### Challenges in Historical Periodization

Historical periodization presents challenges. Before moving forward, it is important to better understand the concepts of periodization.

Mathematics in History

Mathematical boundaries () play a crucial role in marking archaeological periods. The delimitation of a period is generally based on specific tools or characteristics, such as the use of metals.

When identifying a tool or innovation, one observes, at the beginning of the period (minimum value), the most rudimentary version; as one advances through that period, these tools are improved until they reach their maximum development.

However, tools and technologies can vary from one location to another. In the American continent (*Abya Ayala*), for example, they did not evolve in the same way as in Europe, resulting in distinct archaeological periods. Furthermore, areas such as the Andes and Mesoamerica present their own particularities, which generates significant regional variations in temporal markers (<htcite0>; <htcite1>). For more details, we suggest the works of John Howland Rowe (<htcite2> ; <htcite3>).

Let's look at two examples to better understand these differences.

source.text: National Museum of the American Indian

text.text:
The Three-Age System in America (Abya Ayala)

Understanding other peoples requires much study, in order to avoid misunderstandings. Let's analyze some points from the work of Robert F. Heizer to measure a bit of this complexity:

  • The division of human prehistory into Stone Age, Bronze Age ( - ), and Iron Age ( - ) (Heizer, R. F., ).
  • The author uses expressions that suggest a view that Indigenous peoples were inferior compared to Europeans (Heizer, R. F., , pp. 260 - 261). Something demonstrated false on another page of History Tracers (History Tracers, , Who Said Indigenous People Are Different?).
  • Heizer also discusses the deconstruction of the idea that the Earth was only 6,000 years old (Heizer, R. F., , pp. 261 - 262).

Before proceeding with the subject of the ages, we must address the idea of the Indigenous peoples of the Americas (Abya Yala) as “savages.” It is an old view that reflects a lack of understanding of the cultural and historical richness of these peoples.

The Caral civilization, in Peru (Ruta Caral, ; Youtube - Caral Perú Oficial, ; de la Morena, Raquel, , Los misterios de la ciudad más antigua de América ; Moras, Roberto., ), is one of the oldest civilizations in the world. Despite its recent discovery, we can affirm that it possessed complex constructions (Figure 1) and that perhaps it developed a writing system (Mann, Charles C., , pp. 1008 ; History Tracers, , A escrita; Mann, Charles C., , pp. 1008).
Figure 1: Pyramid H1 at the Caral archaeological site (Ruta Caral, ; Youtube - Caral Perú Oficial, ). Photo taken on , during a visit to the site.

A few millennia later, in the north of the continent, the city of Teotihuacan (Figure 2) flourished, with an estimated population of 100,000 inhabitants, becoming the sixth largest city in the world in its time (INAH, ).

Figure 2: General view of Teotihuacan. Photo taken on , during a visit to the site.

Ancient and complex structures like these could not be built without knowledge and organization.

Only Iron?

Another important point related to the lack of knowledge about Indigenous peoples is the classification of historical periods based exclusively on metals such as iron.

Metallurgy was already practiced in the Americas (Abya Yala), with known works in copper (Cu), silver (Ag), and gold (Au) in the southern part of the continent for at least three millennia (Guédron, S., et al., ). There is also evidence that this technology spread to the northern part of the continent via maritime routes (Abya Yala) (Hosler, D., ).

#### A More General View

Given the scenario we have presented for America (*Abya Yala*), we can reflect on the planet as a whole.

Reflection 2: And Now?

If periodization fails in America, could it fail in other locations?

Although we are all of the same species, over time each people developed their own identity. For this reason, we have come to treat historical periods according to the regions in which they lived and their respective cultures.

### Periods of Africa

When we speak of humanity in Africa, limiting ourselves only to the last few millennia, when writing emerged, can lead readers to erroneous conclusions. Among the innumerable qualities existing on this continent is the possibility of using, in depth, interdisciplinarity to understand the origin of our species.

The Natural History Museum has a chart demonstrating the evolution of hominins until reaching our species (<htcite0>). On this page, we reproduce part of the chart, associating it with what we will study.
Chart 1: Simplified cladogram of our species.

Next, we present a table related to the periods of the African continent. As content from other nations is introduced to History Tracers, it will continue to be updated. Furthermore, we will also place side by side the period used by European scholars (<htcite0>; <htcite1>; <htcite2>; <htcite3>) to simplify comparisons.

text.text: Note, in **Chart 1** and **Table 1**, that hominins emerged millions of years ago in Africa (<htcite0>), while our species emerged only approximately 300,000 years ago (<htcite1>). This scenario leads us to a conclusion that often goes unnoticed and deserves reflection.

text.text:
Reflection 3: We are all...

Have you ever stopped to think that we are all African?

### Periods in Asia

The fact that Asia is connected by land to Africa meant that this continent was the second to be occupied not only by our species (**Figure 3**), but also by other species of the genus *Homo*, such as *Homo erectus* (<htcite0>).

source.text: Husson, L., Salles, T., Lebatard, AE. et al

text.text: Figure 3: Human migration map. .

Given this scenario, we proceed to list the periods used for the study of Asia.

In **Table 2**, we present the periods used in China (Zhongguo 中國) and in Europe. As other nations are added to *History Tracers*, the table will be updated. Regarding China (Zhongguo 中國), according to the sources consulted, since <htdate0> its periods are defined according to the dynasties that ruled the nation (<htcite0>).

text.text:
Archaeological Periods in the Americas (Abya Yala)

While it is generally accepted that human presence on the American continent dates back approximately 13,500 years, recent studies suggest the possibility of an earlier arrival, around 30,000 years ago (Roca-Rada, Xavier, et al., , pp. 2 ; Becerra-Valdivia, L., Higham, T., ; Pirula, ). These discrepancies highlight the evolving nature of knowledge (Ferro Virginia, Maria. Virgina ), facilitated by the scientific method (History Tracers, , Scientific Method).

For clarity, we will use the most widely recognized timeframes found in various scholarly sources:

text.text: In different regions, similar names may refer to distinct historical periods. To avoid confusion, it is advisable to always pair period names with their respective region.

### Conclusion The classification of historical periods is inherently tied to the unique development of specific regions. Applying European periodization to other parts of the world, such as the Americas (Abya Yala), can lead to inaccuracies and misunderstandings of local histories. Additionally, these period definitions are subject to change as new discoveries and research continue to reshape our understanding.
